text:
Tropical storm conditions from Cristobal are likely to start Sunday in parts
of southern Louisiana, forecasters said Friday morning.

Update: Metro New Orleans under tropical storm watch ahead of Cristobal

A tropical storm watch and a storm surge watch will likely be issued for a
portion of the Gulf Coast later Friday.

Cristobal, which is currently over land in Mexico, is expected to move north
through the Gulf of Mexico and make landfall along Louisiana's central coast
late Sunday night or early Monday.

Gov. John Bel Edwards has issued an emergency declaration for the state in
advance of the storm.

A flood watch is in effect for most of southeast Louisiana through 7 a.m.
Tuesday, and forecasters issued a tropical storm watch Friday morning for some
of Louisiana's coastal waters.

Where is Tropical Storm Cristobal?

As of 4 a.m. Friday, Cristobal was over land about 80 miles southeast of
Campeche, Mexico, the National Hurricane Center said. It had sustained winds
of 35 mph.

It has completed a slow loop and is heading northeast at 7 mph, forecasters
said.

It's expected to continue moving north through the Gulf of Mexico Friday and
Saturday and approach Louisiana's coast Sunday.

Strengthening expected?

Cristobal weakened Thursday and became less organized overnight, forecasters
said Friday morning.

The storm is expected to stay over land for another 12 to 18 hours,
forecasters said at 4 a.m. Friday, and no change in strength is expected
during that time.

Cristobal is forecast to strengthen once it moves over the Gulf of Mexico and
regain its tropical storm status, meaning wind speeds will exceed 39 mph.

Forecasters said conditions in the Gulf -- specifically, expected moderate
southwesterly wind shear and dry mid-level air -- are not expected to be "very
conducive" for intensification for this storm. However, they said there is
some uncertainty about Cristobal's forecasted strength when it reaches the
Gulf Coast.

Maximum sustained winds of 60 mph are expected at landfall, forecasters said,
which would make it a tropical storm. A Category 1 hurricane has winds of at
74 mph.

Watches and warnings?

A flood watch is in effect for much of Southeast Louisiana, including New
Orleans and Baton Rouge, through 7 a.m. Tuesday. Read the full advisory.

A tropical storm watch is in effect for some of Louisiana's coastal waters.

Tropical storm conditions will likely start Saturday afternoon in the watch
area with winds in excess of 40 knots, the National Weather Service in Slidell
said.

The watch is for outer coastal waters south and west of the mouth of the
Mississippi River.

What should Louisiana expect?

The center of the storm is expected to make landfall along the central
Louisiana coast, but the strongest winds, highest storm surge and heaviest
rains could be "well removed" from the center, forecasters said.

There is a risk of tropical-storm-force winds this weekend from Louisiana to
the western Florida panhandle, forecasters said. There's also a risk of
dangerous storm surge from Louisiana to the Florida Big Bend.

These hazards, along with heavy rainfall, will arrive "well in advance" of
Cristobal and extend well east of the center.

Tropical funnels and tornadoes are also possible as the storm approaches, the
National Weather Service in Slidell said Friday morning.

Tropical storm and storm surge watches will likely be issued Friday for a
portion of the Gulf Coast, forecasters said.

Coastal flooding also is possible.

Wet weather, with occasional heavy rainfall, is expected through the rest of
the week into early next week, the National Weather Service said. "Copious
rainfall" is possible each day, with rainfall rates at times of 2 to 4 inches
per hour.

Rainfall totals over the seven-day period "could easily exceed 10 inches"
within the watch area in southeast Louisiana, the National Weather Service
said.

The heavy rainfall could lead to street flooding and rapid rises of creeks and
streams.

"Drainage systems may approach capacity at times during periods of heaviest
rainfall," the National Weather Service cautioned.

When will it get to Louisiana?

Tropical-storm-force winds from Cristobal could reach New Orleans and
southeast Louisiana as early as Saturday night, National Weather Service
forecasters said.

However, the wind will most likely begin mid-day Sunday, they said, and could
last through Monday.

For the central coast of Louisiana, forecasters with the Lake Charles office
of the National Weather Service said a few rain bands from Cristobal could
reach the area as early as Saturday afternoon, with rain increasing and
becoming more widespread Sunday into Monday.

Emergency declaration for Louisiana

Gov. John Bel Edwards issued an emergency declaration Thursday night that
allows state agencies to take emergency actions involving the storm and sets
the stage for future federal financial relief, if necessary.

"While it is still too early to know for sure what impact Cristobal could have
on Louisiana, now is the time to make your plans, which should include the
traditional emergency items along with masks and hand sanitizer as we continue
to battle the coronavirus pandemic," Edwards said.

While no evacuations were being considered as of Wednesday, Edwards said the
Governor's Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness is working
to see if evacuees can use hotels and motels, instead of traditional large-
space shelters, if an evacuation is required. If shelters are used, the state
has plans for social distancing inside.

When is the next update?

The next advisory is expected at 10 a.m. from the National Hurricane Center.

Read the full 4 a.m. advisory.

See our full coverage of Tropical Depression Cristobal.

Reporters Mark Schleifstein and Sam Karlin contributed to this story.

title: Tropical storm conditions from Cristobal possible Sunday in Louisiana: see latest track
html:
Tropical storm conditions from Cristobal are likely to start Sunday in parts of southern Louisiana, forecasters said Friday morning.

Update: Metro New Orleans under tropical storm watch ahead of Cristobal

A tropical storm watch and a storm surge watch will likely be issued for a portion of the Gulf Coast later Friday.

Cristobal, which is currently over land in Mexico, is expected to move north through the Gulf of Mexico and make landfall along Louisiana's central coast late Sunday night or early Monday.

Gov. John Bel Edwards has issued an emergency declaration for the state in advance of the storm.

A flood watch is in effect for most of southeast Louisiana through 7 a.m. Tuesday, and forecasters issued a tropical storm watch Friday morning for some of Louisiana's coastal waters.

Where is Tropical Storm Cristobal?

As of 4 a.m. Friday, Cristobal was over land about 80 miles southeast of Campeche, Mexico, the National Hurricane Center said. It had sustained winds of 35 mph.

It has completed a slow loop and is heading northeast at 7 mph, forecasters said.

It's expected to continue moving north through the Gulf of Mexico Friday and Saturday and approach Louisiana's coast Sunday.

Strengthening expected?

Cristobal weakened Thursday and became less organized overnight, forecasters said Friday morning.

The storm is expected to stay over land for another 12 to 18 hours, forecasters said at 4 a.m. Friday, and no change in strength is expected during that time.

Cristobal is forecast to strengthen once it moves over the Gulf of Mexico and regain its tropical storm status, meaning wind speeds will exceed 39 mph.

Forecasters said conditions in the Gulf -- specifically, expected moderate southwesterly wind shear and dry mid-level air -- are not expected to be "very conducive" for intensification for this storm. However, they said there is some uncertainty about Cristobal's forecasted strength when it reaches the Gulf Coast.

Maximum sustained winds of 60 mph are expected at landfall, forecasters said, which would make it a tropical storm. A Category 1 hurricane has winds of at 74 mph.

Watches and warnings?

A flood watch is in effect for much of Southeast Louisiana, including New Orleans and Baton Rouge, through 7 a.m. Tuesday. Read the full advisory.

A tropical storm watch is in effect for some of Louisiana's coastal waters.

Tropical storm conditions will likely start Saturday afternoon in the watch area with winds in excess of 40 knots, the National Weather Service in Slidell said.

The watch is for outer coastal waters south and west of the mouth of the Mississippi River.

What should Louisiana expect?

The center of the storm is expected to make landfall along the central Louisiana coast, but the strongest winds, highest storm surge and heaviest rains could be "well removed" from the center, forecasters said.

There is a risk of tropical-storm-force winds this weekend from Louisiana to the western Florida panhandle, forecasters said. There's also a risk of dangerous storm surge from Louisiana to the Florida Big Bend.

These hazards, along with heavy rainfall, will arrive "well in advance" of Cristobal and extend well east of the center.

Tropical funnels and tornadoes are also possible as the storm approaches, the National Weather Service in Slidell said Friday morning.

Tropical storm and storm surge watches will likely be issued Friday for a portion of the Gulf Coast, forecasters said.

Coastal flooding also is possible.

Wet weather, with occasional heavy rainfall, is expected through the rest of the week into early next week, the National Weather Service said. "Copious rainfall" is possible each day, with rainfall rates at times of 2 to 4 inches per hour.

Rainfall totals over the seven-day period "could easily exceed 10 inches" within the watch area in southeast Louisiana, the National Weather Service said.

The heavy rainfall could lead to street flooding and rapid rises of creeks and streams.

"Drainage systems may approach capacity at times during periods of heaviest rainfall," the National Weather Service cautioned.

When will it get to Louisiana?

Tropical-storm-force winds from Cristobal could reach New Orleans and southeast Louisiana as early as Saturday night, National Weather Service forecasters said.

However, the wind will most likely begin mid-day Sunday, they said, and could last through Monday.

For the central coast of Louisiana, forecasters with the Lake Charles office of the National Weather Service said a few rain bands from Cristobal could reach the area as early as Saturday afternoon, with rain increasing and becoming more widespread Sunday into Monday.

Emergency declaration for Louisiana

Gov. John Bel Edwards issued an emergency declaration Thursday night that allows state agencies to take emergency actions involving the storm and sets the stage for future federal financial relief, if necessary.

"While it is still too early to know for sure what impact Cristobal could have on Louisiana, now is the time to make your plans, which should include the traditional emergency items along with masks and hand sanitizer as we continue to battle the coronavirus pandemic," Edwards said.

While no evacuations were being considered as of Wednesday, Edwards said the Governor's Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness is working to see if evacuees can use hotels and motels, instead of traditional large-space shelters, if an evacuation is required. If shelters are used, the state has plans for social distancing inside.

When is the next update?

The next advisory is expected at 10 a.m. from the National Hurricane Center.

Read the full 4 a.m. advisory.

See our full coverage of Tropical Depression Cristobal.

Reporters Mark Schleifstein and Sam Karlin contributed to this story.
